an9.41:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Mallas, near the Mallian town named Uruvelakappa.
an9.41:4.2: Then the Buddha got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, entered Uruvelakappa for alms.
an9.41:4.3: Then, after the meal, when he had returned from alms-round, he addressed Venerable Ānanda:
an9.41:4.4: “Ānanda, you stay right here, while I plunge deep into the Great Wood for the day’s meditation.
an9.41:4.6: Then the Buddha plunged deep into the Great Wood and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
an9.41:5.1: Then the householder Tapussa went up to Venerable Ānanda,
an9.41:5.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
an9.41:6.1: “Sir, Ānanda, we are laypeople who enjoy sensual pleasures. We like sensual pleasures, we love them and take joy in them.
an9.41:6.2: But renunciation seems like an abyss.
an9.41:6.3: I have heard that in this teaching and training there are very young mendicants whose minds are eager for renunciation; they’re confident, settled, and decided about it. They see it as peaceful.
an9.41:6.4: Renunciation is the dividing line between between the multitude and the mendicants in this teaching and training.”
an9.41:7.1: “Householder, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
an9.41:7.2: Come, let’s go to the Buddha
an9.41:7.4: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
an9.41:8.2: Then Ānanda together with Tapussa went to the Buddha,
an9.41:8.3: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an9.41:8.4: Ānanda told him what had happened.
an9.41:10.1: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!
an9.41:10.2: Before my awakening—when I was unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought:
an9.41:10.4: But my mind wasn’t eager for renunciation; it wasn’t confident, settled, and decided about it. I didn’t see it as peaceful.
an9.41:10.6: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason why my mind isn’t eager for renunciation, and not confident, settled, and decided about it? Why don’t I see it as peaceful?’
an9.41:10.8: ‘I haven’t seen the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, and so I haven’t cultivated that. I haven’t realized the benefits of renunciation, and so I haven’t developed that.
an9.41:10.9: That’s why my mind isn’t eager for renunciation, and not confident, settled, and decided about it. And it’s why I don’t see it as peaceful.’
an9.41:10.11: ‘Suppose that, seeing the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, I was to cultivate that. And suppose that, realizing the benefits of renunciation, I was to develop that. It’s possible that my mind would be eager for renunciation; it would be confident, settled, and decided about it. And I would see it as peaceful.’
an9.41:10.12: And so, after some time, I saw the drawbacks of sensual pleasures and cultivated that, and I realized the benefits of renunciation and developed that.
an9.41:10.13: Then my mind was eager for renunciation; it was confident, settled, and decided about it. I saw it as peaceful.
an9.41:10.14: And so, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, I entered and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
an9.41:10.15: While I was in that meditation, perceptions and attentions accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me, and that was an affliction for me.
an9.41:10.17: Suppose a happy person was to experience pain; that would be an affliction for them.
an9.41:10.18: In the same way, when perceptions and attentions accompanied by sensual pleasures beset me, that was an affliction for me.
an9.41:11.2: ‘Why don’t I, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled …
an9.41:11.3: enter and remain in the second absorption.’

an9.41:12.2: ‘Why don’t I, with the fading away of rapture, enter and remain in the third absorption, where I will meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.”’

an9.41:19.1: As long as I hadn’t entered into and withdrawn from these nine progressive meditative attainments in both forward and reverse order, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
an9.41:19.2: But when I had entered into and withdrawn from these nine progressive meditative attainments in both forward and reverse order, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
an9.41:19.3: Knowledge and vision arose in me:
an9.41:19.4: ‘My freedom is unshakeable; this is my final birth; now there are no more future lives.’”
